Is broadband access a human rights issue and a social justice matter? Yes — marginalized communities are being left behind in the digital divide::: according to a new article co-authored by KU’s Edward Scanlon::: associate professor of social welfare.  NEWS.KU.EDU Digital divide as social justice
column3: There are other options besides cable or land based internet. Why should the government spends tens of thousands of dollars to run lines to a rural home when they can get satellite internet without the cables and without additional infrastructure? Or::: is this a ploy to send more dollars to the cable companies so they can increase their bottom line at taxpayer expense?
column4: The rural electric cooperatives are in the best position to supply this utility service. Granted::: they need some funding to accomplish this. True hardships are on New Mexico reservations where other utilities like running water are missing.
column5: The alma mater has a screwy definition of rights. A thing is not a right if it compels action by another.

column7: No. It's a utility. My grandparents didn't have running water when they were children. Wtf is this nonsense?

column1: Budig Hall is home to some of KU’s biggest classes. Where’s your favorite classroom? (Bonus points if you shout out a prof 🧑🏻‍🏫)
column3: I was on the hill at the time it was closed for renovations! So no favorite room. I’d love to tour the inside someday. ~ Jana
column4: Like a few others::: it burned the summer before my freshman year::: and renovations weren’t complete until after I was gone.  It’s always bothered me that I never went in that building::: and I think I’ll get really emotional when I finally do.
column5: I never had the chance to take a class in Budig Hall - it was burned out Hoch Auditorium the whole time I was there. The lightening strike happened the summer before my freshman year.  Bonus though - one of my roommates at Douthart Hall my freshman year was a senior and she came up with a great Halloween costume theme for all 4 of us in our room for the Blood Bash (Halloween costume party held every year at the hall). She was Hoch::: complete with lightening bolts and flames and the rest of us were fire fighters 😂
column6: I took a general anthropology class there in the late '60s. Hundreds of students and the professor's TAs took role from a seating chart. If you were in the wrong seat::: you were absent.
column7: I registered at Hoch back in the day when we enrolled at Allen. I saw the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band and REM in that building...
column8: I had my first western civ class in Hoch auditorium with hundreds of my friends 😉 then my social work graduation ceremony in there weeks before the fire in 1991
column9: Old Hoch was a classic venue. I was a kid when it burned::: but I did get to attend some events in there. It would still be a favorite classroom if it was standing today. I saw the lightning strike from about 10 miles away. I knew that it had hit something.
column10: It’ll always be Hoch Auditorium to me. Had Chemistry with the illustrious Clark Bricker there and attended annual Holiday Vespers and other concerts (R.E.M::: Husker Du) in that space. It was a sad thing to witness it burning on that June day in 1991.
column11: Anthropology 101 with Dr. Bill Bass in Hoch Auditorium in the '60s.
column12: Not that building but Hoch. Took chemistry with Clark Bricker. Best prof ever!!!
column13: Biology in one of the huge classrooms in Wescoe with Del Shankel.
column14: I took CS200 there when it was Hoch. I have no idea who taught it::: though.
column15: Math 125 was my shiz with Professor Daniel James
column16: I took Biology 101 in Budig... standout memory was watching the twin towers fall on 9/11 on the large screens.
column17: I had several classes in the biggest lecture room in the middle of Budig from 2008 to 2012. I remember going through the dark lower level a lot of times and people would be sleeping in a dark hallway outside of a computer room. That’s one of my favorite buildings on campus::: and the outside was so pretty ❤️💙❤️💙
column18: Got a lot of interesting symbolism all over that building…
column19: Never got to experience the legend of Hoch/Budig.
column20: Intro to Psychology…had 1000 people in my class…it was AWESOME!!!
column22: Who discovered the passage from Budig to the library?!? Spent a decent share of my first two years there in computer lab. Classes there… ECON 101:::102; Physics 101::: Accounting 1::: Chem 1
column23: Hoch —Dr Bass Anthropology one 1968
column24: I had it::: too. Taught by someone who worked for the KBI::: I think. I was very impressed with him.
column25: Saw the Righteous Brothers in the auditorium.
column26: Economics with professor Shaffer!
column27: Frazier Hall
column29: I had financial accounting with Tim Shaftel in one of those classrooms. One of my most memorable classes…20 years ago!
column30: The old photo lab in the basement of Flint…..many moons ago.
column31: Remember taKing Intro to Poetry during the beautiful Spring with Dr. Frank Nelick in Fraser. I adored him!!

Throughout the existence of the Islamic Republic of Iran::: the slogan has formed a pillar of its revolutionary values. It is regularly chanted at Friday prayers and other public events::: which is often accompanied by a burning of the flag of the United States.

column9: Still existing: Strong. But favorite in my long experience: The one story converted U.S. wood military barracks that were installed (probably just after WW II?) behind Strong for at least close to three decades through the '60s.. These were the province of political science::: and perhaps another department or two. Especially nice were the classrooms at the ends of the buildings: Numerous double-hung windows in 3 of the 4 walls::: open fall and spring::: birds singing::: breeze in the pines::: human scale and comfortable as old shoes. Ronnie Averyt::: Earl Nehring::: Ed Stene::: Eldon Fields::: Jim Drury::: James Titus::: and more...Ethan Allen (with fedora always) and Rhodes Scholar Walter Sandelius (mainly classical theory (I did a directed reading with him::: and in another class he sponsored a monthly gathering at his home complete with sherry and a little munchy ... for a Kansas guy that was impossibly exotic.) And Jaroslav P. ... whose biography he sketched out for an audience in 2003 at the dedication of the Dole Center. Unbelievable - truly. So anyway::: I think Snow was a reasonable replacement -\-\ classrooms with lots of glass::: each floor compact -\-\ though a "coffee room" would have been a big plus. ... How buildings dredge up memories... :-)

column1: A KU professor’s new book::: “Drug Lords::: Cowboys and Desperados: Violent Myths of the U.S.-Mexico Frontier:::” says good-versus-evil tropes — such as white-hatted cowboys or vicious drug lords —have led to real-life oppression of ethnic minorities.  NEWS.KU.EDU Deconstructing Western myths
column3: GIVE ME a BREAK! The author insinuates that the only reason why Ronald Reagan got elected President of the United States is because he was a cowboy actor. The issue I have with that is that he stopped acting about twenty years before he took office. In fact::: he had been the governor of California before being elected POTUS::: and had served more than one term as such::: he had strong political background. Moreover::: his POTUS predecessor was none other than Jimmy Carter::: whose anemic economic policies and noncommittal response to the Iranian hostage crisis were both seen as his political downfall. In addition::: inflation::: a stagnant economy and weakness of Carter's policies paved the way for Reagan to be elected into office- *NOT* whether or not he wore a cowboy hat. Reagan ran for president a total of three times- in 1968::: 1976::: and a third time in 1980. If his cowboy image had ANY BEARING in his election AT *ALL!*::: he would have won the first time. Therefore::: the author's stance is factually wrong. Reagan was a Republican. Jimmy Carter was a Democrat. Ronald Reagan promised economic prosperity and a reduction of government as well as the reduction of "inflation"::: two policies which he delivered on. His hatlessness::: at the time::: was not a problem. Jimmy Carter was seen at the time as being one of the weakest presidents in the previous fifty years::: which is why he got bounced after only FOUR years. He also attempts to convey the idea that El Chapo Guzman is "vilified" and misunderstood::: essentially because of his skin color. No::: I thank you-the man is villified because he sells illegal narcotics and murders people; he's not a "Hispanic Jesus".  I do hope this is satire; his ideas about Reagan elicited more than a few guffaws.  Let's stick to what the facts ARE::: not what we WANT them to BE just so we can publish.

column1: We have made the decision to allow attendees to assemble on the Hill during Sunday’s Commencement exercises. Non-graduates should stay clear of the walkways at all times to allow our students to process smoothly. With caution and consideration::: this tradition can continue.
column3: KU's incompetence in handling this whole day is staggering. Abysmal::: untimely communication. No contingency plans. Oof.
column4: I find it very hard to believe that a major university such as this one::: would neglect to exhaust all options before cancelling commencement ceremonies. I work at an institution who::: in planning for the weather::: had Plan B months in advance. They made the executive decision to utilize an indoor accommodation three days ahead of graduation and all was well. With the new CDC guidelines of 3 ft. social distancing could have been managed in::: say::: the Basketball Arena? Please allow these students who have come through such a difficult academic year to participate in a time-honored tradition without doing it virtually. Signed::: A 2021 MS.Ed Graduate
column5: Such disappointment in the decision to cancel today’s graduation. There’s absolutely no excuse. Make it so bad the forecast has shown rain for today for the past week! And you owed it to the students and their families to have a back up plan down to the day. With that said::: you should have something today / tonight for them.
column6: I don’t know if not being able to hold commencement indoors was so much a COVID thing for other universities like Kansas State was able to move their ceremonies indoors due to inclement weather. I don’t know if it’s more so upholding the tradition of walking down the hill. Unfortunately::: we are in the time of year where the weather is so unpredictable and severe weather is highest. Honestly::: graduates can walk down the hill on their own. I still think everyone would’ve actually liked a formal ceremony wherever that be::: indoor or outdoor. As a 2021 graduate I would’ve been fine with that. Unfortunately we may not be able to stick with the tradition that’s been around::: but we get something::: especially since we have all worked so hard.
column7: KU failed these graduates and families in so many way this past year. Online did not work for many::: they essentially made the students teach themselves. Why were they charged full tuition::: when professors didn't answer emails::: had no office hours::: gave tests but didn't post grades grades until around Xmas. My grandson had no idea how he was even doing in the class. Professors were too lazy to plan and carry out graduation for their department when their were plenty of places at Ku that could have accommodated their students and family. Graduates also not helped to find jobs after graduation. Then::: the topper::: canceling graduation exercises when they knew a week in advance it was supposed to rain. They made no effort to make alternative plans. My girls and their husband's::: and my granddaughter went to KU had a wonderful experience. Yes::: it was a different year with covid::: but you could have done a better job. Too many were left to to teach themselves without any from their professors and they need to be accountable for their failures. You charged full tuition and gave the students very little teaching. You have failed as an institution that has been in the past a great school. Leave the politics out your video on honors graduation::: it was not appropriate!

column7: I find it very hard to believe that a major university such as this one::: would neglect to exhaust all options before cancelling commencement ceremonies. With the new CDC guidelines of 3 ft. social distancing could have been managed in::: say::: the Basketball Arena? column5: I was walking to class one morning when I met a man in a comical outfit. I decided it was worth being late to my class to figure out who this was::: so I turned around and followed him. He walked into Hoch Auditorium::: down the center aisle::: to the front of the room. I found an empty seat and sat down. It was Dr. Bricker and his final lecture of the semester. I could not remember what class I was heading to::: but I will not forget following him to his lecture.
column6: I had Western Civ there in little cubicles on the floor. Very distracting! But I did manage to pass the course! Also remember picking up enrollment cards there::: maybe for Spring semester! 1966

column13: 1984 or 85::: when it was just Hoch auditorium::: I believe it was a Chem 184 course with Dr. Earl Huyser::: with hundreds of classmates. Good times!
column14: Chem 150 in Hoch Auditorium. And freshman convocation. And "Into the Woods" on the stage!
column15: Went to concerts at Hoch Auditorium before the fire and name change
column16: My freshman registration in the fall of ‘88 was in Hoch Auditorium. I missed the fire a few years later (I was home for the summer)::: but::: boy...what a shock it was to come back to campus and see the charred shell of the old place.
column17: In the late 60's::: I enrolled in one of KU's most popular classes and it was held in Hoch. Dr. William Bass's Anthropology 1 classes were held there::: and were the "largest" classes at KU at that time. The auditorium::: including the balcony were full for his lectures. Dr. Bass was very big on human anatomy::: human remains identification and was famous for his risque lectures. One of his bawdy lecture events was written up in Readers Digest back then.  Dr. Bass left KU for the University of Tennessee::: where he established the famed "body farm" to study human decomposition::: an idea he conceived while at KU.
column18: The class was bigger than my hometown. Greek and Roman Mythology::: 8am Tue/Thu. It was my welcome to a big::: public university. And I loved it.
column19: I saw a very funny comedian (wearing a white suit and with arrow through his head) as the warm up act to the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band there in about '73.
column20: Many Chemistry classes in old Hoch.
column21: I had chemistry with the infamous Clark Bricker in Hoch auditorium and I enjoyed various concerts there::: including the annual Vespers and R.E.M. It was a sad day when it burned.
column22: I had Chem 184 in Hoch Auditorium before the fire. Albert Burgstahler was the prof. I also had a US history course in there. I recall pulling an all-nighter prepping for the final exam. When I arrived at the final::: we were told there was a bomb threat and the final would be a take-home final. Needless to say::: I was not happy.
column23: No::: but had Chemistry 184 in Hoch Auditorium with almost 1:::000 of my closest Freshmen friends. Probably why I never became that Engineer I thought I wanted to be. Thank God for unanswered prayers.
column24: Concerts to include my first opera. Unfortunately - I watched it burn::: It was surreal.
column25: Nothing compared to lectures in Hoch Auditorium though. :)

KU::: even though I have never once been::: is where I am heading.

column1: The pandemic led to a postponement of traditional KU Commencement exercises last year::: and COVID-19 precautions continue to affect campus events. Jayhawks usually gather today at Strong Hall to take part in a New Orleans-style second line band march to honor the life and work of Martin Luther King Jr. While that traditional #MLKday march won’t take place this year::: there are still many upcoming opportunities to join the conversation locally::: including these:  🗓️ JAN. 20 | 7-8 p.m. | Join the KU Department of African and African-American Studies and Lawrence Public Library on Zoom for “Where Do We Go From Here: Chaos or Community?” KU professors Shawn Alexander::: Randal Jelks::: and Dorthy Pennington explore the classic question posed by King while incorporating perspectives gained in 2020. REGISTER: https://lawrence.bibliocommons.com/events/5fa074ce17d56731005e90bf  🗓️ FEB. 1 | Join KU’s Office of Multicultural Affairs for “Beyond the King:::” a social media takeover that aims to educate the community on the many different people who made the civil rights movement – and King’s work – possible but are often left out of conversations around this time of year.

Kennedy.

column1: Did you know a visual artistic link — two stone owls staring at each other across Jayhawk Boulevard — has existed for nearly 120 years between Dyche Hall (dedicated in 1902)::: and Spooner Hall (1894)? You can find Dyche’s owl carved into the top corbel of the main entry arch::: staring at the older owl in Spooner’s red sandstone gable.  According to footnotes in the “Dashing Kansan” – a biography of the building’s namesake::: Lewis Lindsay Dyche – blueprints show Dyche’s ornamental owl was to have been carved freestanding::: perched atop the corbel of the building’s main entryway rather than into the corbel itself.

column1: 💌 Dear Jayhawks: Things were hard this semester::: but you showed up to learn. Things were new::: but you showed up to teach and serve. Things were stressful::: but you proved that — despite the challenges – you are adaptable::: resolute::: and willing to do your part.  As we move into remote study and finals weeks::: remember: The work isn’t done and it isn’t easy::: but it is definitely worth it. Wear your masks::: physically distance::: and — as always — Rock Chalk. We’ll see you back on the Hill in February.

As a remarkable semester winds down::: the entire KU community::: especially our students::: should take pride in the shared sacrifice that allowed our campus to reopen safely. We look forward to the spring and::: with the hard work of Jayhawks leading the way::: a return to normalcy.

column1: The Jayhawk community is saddened by Tuesday’s death of Gene Budig::: 81::: KU’s 14th chancellor (1981-1994). Budig::: an academic and an experienced university administrator::: presided over a period of extensive campus growth. He also led the effort to rebuild Hoch Auditorium after a devastating fire caused by a lightning strike. The building now bears his name. An avid baseball fan::: Budig went on to become president of baseball’s American League. Read more about his legacy: https://kuhistory.ku.edu/articles/budig-bat.

column1: Waiting for your next class? Avoid hanging around hallways. Instead::: try waiting outside or in a large::: well-ventilated area.  📍 Use this map to locate indoor and outdoor study spaces on campus (it works best with Firefox): https://opsmaps.ku.edu/index.html  ⛺ You can wait in one of eight outdoor study spaces — white tents set up around campus. Each tent has WiFi (use the “Jayhawk” network)::: electricity for charging laptops and phones::: and is arranged for healthy physical distancing.  🏫 If you’d like to stay inside::: we suggest one of our designated indoor study spaces. There are over 20 locations on campus::: each offering areas for students to hang out or study in a healthy::: physically distanced environment.  📚 KU libraries are open for quiet and study time::: at reduced capacity. column3: https:// www.facebook.com /groups/ 2935909079818694 /?ref=share
column4: wtf
column5: The whole point of makeup is to have fun and accentuate your features. I don't think anyone putting on their eyeliner does it with the intention of imitating another race::: unless they're cosplayers or work in the theater::: and then it's because they're becoming a specific character. Moreover it's called FOX EYE makeup::: not ASIAN EYE makeup. If you look at a fox's eye::: it makes sense where the trend gets its name. But for the sake of the argument::: if fox eye makeup counts as cultural appropriation::: what about cat eye makeup? The styles are pretty similar looking. Do we need to stop wearing that too? Should non-asians get upset about Koreans using double eyelid tape or doing cut creases? Should we also restrict the colors that people of different races are allowed to dye their hair if it's not a color that commonly occurs in their racial or ethnic group?  I don't believe anything about this trend is racist. Telling people they can't wear it if they're not a certain race::: on the other hand::: most definitely is. If seeing people of all colors and backgrounds elongating the wings on their eyeliner ruins your day::: perhaps you should be reexamining your own values and rethinking your own views on race. At the very least::: please get a hobby 🙄

column1: ⚠️ Heads up::: Jayhawks — your fall 2020 class schedules may have changed as result of KU’s efforts to reconfigure the semester and allow for greater health and safety measures. You should have received an email with full details. Here are the basic things to know and how we can help.  📌 View your schedule First::: you’ll need to access your class schedule. Log in to Enroll & Pay (sa.ku.edu). From the student homepage::: go to the Manage Classes tile. From there::: you should be able to view your schedule.  📌 Check for changes Certain details about your classes will likely have changed since you enrolled. Check closely for updates to: • meeting time • class frequency • location • course delivery mode (in person::: online::: or blended instruction)  Take note of each class’s location — some may alternate between in-person class time and Zoom.  📌 Update your schedule These changes may not work for you. If that’s the case::: contact your advisor. They’ll work with you to identify alternative class options and adjust your schedule in Enroll & Pay.  Or::: you can change your schedule yourself. For more info on how to do that::: go to sis.ku.edu/enrollpay-student.  If you do wish to make changes to your schedule::: do so as soon as possible and no later than Aug. 28 (the deadline to receive a full refund after dropping a class).  Thank you for your patience as we work toward a healthy fall semester. We couldn’t do this without the feedback and support of our outstanding student community.

column1: Many of KU Libraries’ 5.6 million print items are shelved in labyrinthine stacks at Watson Library::: which opened Sept. 11::: 1924. column5: Personally::: I love card catalogues....A ND I enjoy just browsing-\-\that' s when you have some of the best 'finds'!!
column6: This is a "recent" photo. There was a time when Watson's gothic reading room was intact. The atmospherics of which were just beyond wonderful. If I had a few hundred million I'd see about "inticing" the university - into a restoration of the reading room::: and a major re-do of the rest of Watson::: to include an adequate and modern stack system which would involve removing the old nursing school residence behind watson (Not Watkins::: the old hospital...) constructing those stacks/ reading-study areas so as to take advantage of the vistas across the Wakarusa valley. :-) RE Catalogue: certainly much easier to find a specific::: known item::: or to browse through dozens of subject::: and sub sub sub-subject headings... but browsing through a small segment - nothing beats a physical catalogue imo.

It is still traumatic after almost fifty years. 😳 😀
